snippet: While the Obama administration has promised to increase the number of refugees the United States accepts, the process for vetting and admitting them takes up to two years.

byline.contributor: Somini Sengupta reported from the United Nations, and Anne Barnard from Beirut, Lebanon. Maher Samaan contributed reporting from Beirut.
byline.original: By SOMINI SENGUPTA and ANNE BARNARD

abstract: Refugees from Iraq and Syria who applied for United States asylum have indefinite wait to complete process because US embassy outside Beirut is under renovation and officials will not house immigration officers overnight anywhere else; bureaucratic hurdle is just one of many that is hampering resettlement efforts and exacerbating crisis.

keywords.value: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
keywords.name: subject

lead_paragraph: While the Obama administration has promised to increase the number of refugees the United States accepts, the process for vetting and admitting them takes up to two years.

headline.print_headline: Refugees, Stuck in Grinding U.S. Process, Wait and Hope
headline.main: Refugees, Stuck in Grinding U.S. Process, Wait and Hope
